review.title: Proceedings of the First International Workshop on Argumentation in Logic Programming and Non-Monotonic Reasoning (Arg-LPNMR 2016)
review.abstract: This volume contains the papers presented at Arg-LPNMR 2016: First International Workshop on Argumentation in Logic Programming and Nonmonotonic Reasoning held on July 8-10, 2016 in New York City, NY.

sections.heading: 5 Aggregating Opinions in Abstract Argumentation
sections.text: Richard BoothTechnical Talks 7 7 Collaborative Planning and Decision Support for Practical Reasoning in Decentralized Supply ChainsNaeem Janjua 15 Revision of Abstract Dialectical Frameworks: Preliminary ReportThomas Linsbichler, Stefan WoltranvviSAT-Based Approaches to Reasoning about Reasoning Frameworks к, Matti Järvisalo Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT, Department of Computer Science, University of Helsinki, FinlandIntroduction Argumentation is a central theme in modern Artistic Intelligence (AI) research [Bench-Capon and Dunne, 2007] with links to a range of scientific disciplines, from computational complexity theory and automated reasoning to philosophy and social sciences, with applications to domains such as legal reasoning, multiagent systems and decision support (AFs).

sections.heading: An argument is a reason or justification of a claim.
sections.text: In this lecture we will present the basics of semantics, i.e. key concepts and principles on which an evaluation is based. Each concept (principle) is described by an axiom. We will then present two families of semantics: semantics of expansion and semantics of ranking. We will analyze them based on the axioms that shed light on the assumptions and decisions they make. It will also allow a clear comparison between semantics of the same family and semantics of expansion and ranking.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: An argument gives rise to support a claim that is questionable, or open to doubt. It consists of three components: premises that represent the reason, a conclusion that is the claim supported, and a link that shows how the premises lead to the conclusion. Thus, the link is the logical "adhesives" that link premises and conclusions together. An argument has an intrinsic strength that can come from various sources: the certainty of reason [Amgoud and Cayrol, 2002], the meaning of the value it promotes, if any [Bench-Capon, 2003], the reliability of its source [Parsons et al., 2011]. Whatever its intrinsic strength is (strong or weak), an argument can be attacked by other arguments. An attack amounts to undermining one of the components of an argument, and thus has a negative impact on its goal. An assessment of the general strength (or general acceptance) of an argument becomes compelling.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Background
sections.text: The problem of judgment aggregation (YES), i.e. the problem of aggregating the opinions of a group of agents q, through a series of logically related proposals, has recently received much attention from researchers in multi-agent systems, philosophy and economics. In this lecture, we report on current and ongoing work on a version of this problem in defining abstract argumentations.We proceed from a fixed sentence Ag "t1,.., nu from agents, the arguments of a given reasoning framework (AF) A. Each assessment takes the form of an A-labeling, i.e. an assignment of one of the labels in (the term accepted), from (rejected) or undec (undecided) to each argument of A. Not all possible A-labeling is feasible. The feasible labeling is those that correspond to the respective reasoning semantics.

sections.heading: 3.2 DAUC Interval Methods
sections.text: Interval methods do not satisfy the collective completeness. To correct this, we use the downward permissible and upward open procedures to repair and complete FY pLq. The downward permissible marking ç L of an arbitrary marking L is obtained by re-labelling each illegally undec-labelled argument with undec. The resulting marking is permissible but not necessarily complete. The upward complete marking äL of a given permissible marking is obtained by re-labelling each illegally undec-labelled argument with in or out accordingly. (See [Caminada and Pigozzi, 2011] for details. The DAUC version of an interval method FY is obtained by taking for each given AF A and Aprofile L the argument êFYA pLq as the baseline value. Collective completeness is guaranteed by construction. DAUC interval methods do not satisfy the independence FY, but they satisfy the Fêq argument in Fêoth-L instead.

sections.heading: 3.3 Partial Resolution-based Methods
sections.text: Another way to use a family of intervals Y to define an aggregation method is the partial resolution approach [Baroni et al., 2011]. Suppose a P ArgsA is supported in L ifp | V La: out |, | V La: in | q P Y. Then, let's change A by resolving any mutual attack in favor of Y -based arguments, i.e., if aé b, we remove one of these attacks when it goes from an un-Y -based argument to a Y -based argument. Then, GYApLq is defined by taking the grounded designation of this modified VF. The resulting method GY fulfills the collective completeness. Furthermore, FY and GY provide the same results when confined to the class of symmetric AFs (i.e. AFs, for which each attack is reciprocal).

sections.heading: 3.4 Distance-based Approaches
sections.text: Another approach to aggregation is to base it on an idea of the distance dpL1, L2q between labels. So, for example, at such a distance, we could consider the result of the aggregation as the complete label closest to the group. Of course, it may turn out that we have several narrow labels at the end, which means that the output will be a series of labels and not a single one. We also need to define an appropriate distance measure. One way of doing this is the thematic distance [Stand et al., 2012]. Roughly speaking, the arguments in an AF can be divided into a series of questions, i.e. arguments whose labels are either always equal or always opposite (in vs out) in each complete label. The distance dpL1, L2q is then determined by removing a representative from each output and summarizing diff pL1paq, L2paqq over all of these representatives, with a deviation for the difference between the labels (e.g. dediff, 2).

sections.heading: 4 Further and Ongoing Work
sections.text: We are in the process of extending the results not only to AFs, but also to abstract dialectical frameworks (ADFs). In fact, DAUC interval methods were extended to ADFs in [as of 2015]. Secondly, the exact relationship to YES remains to be investigated: does our setting subsume the YES method or vice versa? Finally, we would like to fully characterize the families of the aggregation methods described here.

sections.heading: 2 State-of-the-art.
sections.text: The collaborative problem in decentralized SCs consists of two intertwined functions: planning and decision support. Planning involves drawing up plans whose success is justified by some evidence from one or more of the SCs trading partners, and decision support to assess the acceptability of these plans by comparing the evidence supporting them with possible objections. A planner needs to think about his actions. Therefore, during joint planning, decision-makers need decision support models for selecting, organizing and reviewing their actions and plans. [7] There is a wealth of planning and decision support work in supply chains that can be divided into the following three categories:

sections.heading: 2.1 Mathematical and analytical based approaches
sections.text: Several supply chain collaboration practices suggested in the literature, such as the Vendor Managed Inventory, Just In Time, Efficient Consumer Response, Continuous Replenishment and Accurate Response, Collaborative Planning, Forecasting and Replenishment (CPFR), focus on better planning through tight processes, integration and the exchange of forecasting information between SC's trading partners. [8] However, these applications either provide little or no decision-making support with regard to the negotiation process. Several researchers introduced a process model that deals with the aspect of decision-making and negotiations between trading partners, while maintaining their local decision-making power [9; 10]. The research approaches discussed above stem from applied mathematics, such as optimization, statistics and decision theory, and act as a black box for decision makers. They absorb information and generate results, but provide no visibility as to the underlying reasoning and justification behind the results. [11] There are limited examples of such adoption in the literature.

sections.heading: 2.2 Logic-based approaches for automated planning and decision making
sections.text: Multi-agent planning systems are advanced planning systems that are applied to independent or loosely coupled problems to enhance the benefits of distributed planning among autonomous software agents. [12] In coordination, software agents working together will build a model of the minds of other agents and update their own beliefs and goals as the dialogue progresses. [13] In order to overcome uncertainties, argument-based frameworks have been proposed that allow various software agents to share knowledge and resolve conflicts between them in order to achieve the common goal. [12] In most GSP systems, however, planning provides the solution, and in its execution it merely traverses the identified path. Such systems work well in closed-world adoption, where all possible effects of any action are known in advance.

sections.heading: 2.3 Logic based approaches supporting planning and decision making
sections.text: The introduction of semantic web technology tools for collaboration has addressed some of the problems of cooperation between SC trading partners, such as the importance of information that makes them comprehensible across organizational boundaries and facilitates the exchange and integration of data. [14] Attempts have been made to present incomplete and conflicting information in information systems such as Dr-Prolog, Dr-Device and situated courtly logic. [15] These implementations represent and address only individual conflicting preferences by defining priorities based on a single criterion between them before engaging in collaboration. Therefore, these attempts do not provide a solution for collaborative planning that is subject to inconsistencies derived from multiple data / information sources and multiple users. Moreover, these techniques have not yet been applied to collaborative planning and decision support domains. [16] The collaborative planning and action model is the first attempt to support planners in managing and planning information and facilitate the planning process with automated reasoning.

sections.heading: 3 Motivation
sections.text: Despite the increasing use of advanced planning tools and technologies, current SC trading partners are far from structured collaborative planning and decision support for practical considerations. Of the various factors, data integration was considered to be one of the core issues in business information systems [17]. Over the last decade, SC trading partners "focus has been on record systems (SoR), i.e. structured data on sales, customer and product information, inventory forecasts, and so on, and it has been used for planning and decision making. As a result, centralized business information systems such as data warehousing systems handled exclusively with record-based data can be carefully mapped by schema-centric mediation approaches from knowledge experts to support planning decisions. In such information systems, business intelligence derived for planning can often provide decision support by answering the questions that relate to patterns," what happens. "To answer questions that relate to patterns, what happens, and why it is necessary to decode.

sections.heading: 4 Proposed conceptual framework
sections.text: This section proposes to coordinate the activities of trading partners in a supply chain. DeLP, which is a universally applicable reasoning formalism based on logical programming, is used to model contradictory and potentially contradictory knowledge. [18] A defective logic program has the form о = (т, х), where "and" stands for strict knowledge (not interpretable) or defective knowledge (provisional). DeLP uses the reasoning formalism to argue about contradictory information by identifying contradictory information in the knowledge base and applying the dialectical process to decide which information prevails during the argumentative reasoning process. DeLP uses the reasoning formalism only to argue about contradictory information, using contradictory information only in the argumentative process to determine which information prevails during the argumentative process.

sections.heading: 4.3 Interleaving planning and reasoning over conflicting preference using meta-argumentation
sections.text: Meta-reasoning is a discussion dialogue that involves participants, sharing responsibility, and participating in the decision of what action or course of action should be taken in a given situation. [26] In such dialogues, participants have no fixed positions at the beginning of the dialogue, and the goal and necessity of action can emanate from each of the participants involved. However, during the course of action, participants can be involved in a persuasion dialogue that can motivate them to model a persuasion dialogue as embedded in a reasoning dialogue. [28] In particular, the following tasks are performed in this sub-goal: A plethora of work exists in building dialogue-based systems for software agents. This research focus on expanding argumentation work through [27] the use of argumentation programs [28]. During the argument process, the relationships between the arguments are linked in a particular pattern to support the final conclusion. Such linkage patterns are referred to as "reasoning and enabling reasoning" and using reasoning under premises.

sections.heading: 4.4 Prototype development and future work
sections.text: Developing to address the needs of different collaborative planning for practical thinking in supply chains is done using Microsoft Visual Studio 20101, NRuler 2, which is a fast production system library based on the RETE algorithm written in C-Sharp. This library is extended for the development of the hybrid reasoning engine. metadata.abstractText: An argument is a reason or justification of a claim. It has an intrinsic strength and may be attacked by other arguments. Hence, the evaluation of its overall strength is mandatory. Such an evaluation is done by acceptability semantics. In this talk, we provide the foundations of a semantics, i.e., key concepts and principles on which an evaluation is based. Each concept (principle) is described by an axiom. We then present two families of semantics: extension semantics and ranking semantics. We analyze them against the axioms shedding thus light on the assumptions and choices they made. The analysis allows also a clear comparison between semantics of the same family, and between extension semantics and ranking ones.
